nodes.body:
I think having it split makes sense (though the `List` function might be a bit artificial).

For `Sym`, it's pretty straightforward -- it's the List version of `Nat.multichoose`, where `+` becomes `++`, and the LHS of `++` you map consing the head of the list. I don't know how much harder the proofs are to carry out.

Thanks you, that's great.

maintainer merge

I think it would make sense to split the material across three files:
* `Data.List.Sym` (new)
* `Data.Multiset.Sym` (new)
* `Data.Finset.Sym`

What do you think?

How hard is it to do the same for `Sym`?

Thanks you, that's great.

maintainer merge

```suggestion
  with multiplicity. The list's values are in `Sym Î± n`.
```
How easy is it to prove that the length is `Nat.multichoose`?

Really easy (see `length_sym` at the end of this file).

I put a good amount of effort into trying to prove `List.Perm.sym`, but I might give up for now. That's the one key lemma to be able to define `Multiset.sym` and (since I have `List.Nodup.sym`) `Finset.sym`.

I think a way to prove it would be to use `sym_map` to switch to a list with `Nodup` and then carry out something like `symOptionSuccEquiv` for lists (use whether the head of the list is in the `Sym` element or not; if it is, erase to undo the `map` in the definition of `sym`).

There's no need to disambiguate using the `_iff` suffix.
```suggestion
theorem sym2_eq_empty : s.sym2 = âˆ… â†” s = âˆ… := by
```
I think `sym2_empty`, `sym2_eq_empty`, `sym2_nonempty` should stay neighboring lemmas

```suggestion
It is the image of `s Ã—Ë¢ s` under the quotient `Î± Ã— Î± â†’ Sym2 Î±`. -/
```
is what you meant, I assume?
I added article
Would you mind formatting this into a nice TODO in the module docs?

```suggestion
```

I can't find where the `Fintype` instance is anymore, but shouldn't this be moved to `Data.Finset.Sym`, or maybe `Data.Fintype.Sym` if we really really care about import scope creep to the point of excluding `Fintype` from those files (and I think we don't care).

The Fintype instance is added in this PR, `instFintypeSym2`, in `Data.Finset.Sym`. There's already enough Fintype stuff imported in that module that it can be defined right there, but someone could refactor and the things that depend on it out if it's worth doing.

The reason this `card` theorem still worked without `instFintypeSym2` is that it used the `Quotient` fintype instance, which needs `DecidableEq`. Now `DecidableEq` is dropped from the type since it's not used.

```suggestion
* A `Fintype (Sym2 Î±)` instance that does not require `DecidableEq Î±`.
```

```suggestion
instance Sym2.instFintype [Fintype Î±] : Fintype (Sym2 Î±) where
```
is the convention as I've understood it.

You can fix it while you're here.
```suggestion
protected alias âŸ¨_, Nonempty.sym2âŸ© := sym2_nonempty
```
Now obsolete

I don't really know what's idiomatic nowadays but I was expecting something like
```suggestion
  | x :: xs => (x :: xs).map (âŸ¦(x, Â·)âŸ§) ++ xs.sym2
```
Using `Â·` didn't work, but I put the spaces around `::`.
Try `(âŸ¦âŸ¨x, Â·âŸ©âŸ§)`. I think the innermost pair of parentheses will be interpreted as enclosing a function notation.
I don't think this is worth changing, but your suggestion probably works (modulo questions about whether it can infer that it should be a Prod).

```suggestion
import Mathlib.Data.Multiset.Sym
```
Can you prove `Monotone sym2`, `StrictMono sym2`, `Injective sym2`?
Sure, though I think that's about the last of the scope creep that I'm willing to entertain!

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: remove `DecidableEq` argument from `Finset.sym2`

nodes.body:
I think it would make sense to split the material across three files:
* `Data.List.Sym` (new)
* `Data.Multiset.Sym` (new)
* `Data.Finset.Sym`

What do you think?

How hard is it to do the same for `Sym`?

I think having it split makes sense (though the `List` function might be a bit artificial).

For `Sym`, it's pretty straightforward -- it's the List version of `Nat.multichoose`, where `+` becomes `++`, and the LHS of `++` you map consing the head of the list. I don't know how much harder the proofs are to carry out.

Thanks you, that's great.

maintainer merge
